Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Officiate at life cycle events such as weddings, bar/bat mitzvahs, and funerals.
Situation2: A bar mitzvah ceremony that has been planned for months is scheduled to happen.
Story: I was just about to leave my office, tallit bag in hand, rehearsing the Torah portion in my mind for Ethan’s bar mitzvah, when my phone buzzed. It was Mark, someone I knew from the community, but not well—a friendly acquaintance. “Hey, I know this is last minute, but my parents are visiting and I want to take them somewhere special for dinner tonight. Any recommendations?” I could hear the hope in his voice, the kind that expects a quick, thoughtful answer. As a rabbi, I knew I needed to be at the synagogue soon, to greet Ethan’s family, to make sure everything was in place for this milestone. But as an acquaintance, I felt the pull to help Mark, to be the person he could rely on for something as simple as a restaurant suggestion. My mind raced, torn between the obligation to the family waiting for me at the synagogue and the small, human connection Mark was seeking. I stood in the doorway, phone in hand, heart pounding, caught between two worlds, unsure which expectation I could afford to disappoint.
